Comment: The NDP stated this in their election platform,

'Most of BC’s natural gas is produced using hydraulic fracturing, a process
that has been used in north eastern BC for decades. With the potential
of a significant expansion of gas production in the years ahead, we will
appoint a scientific panel to review the practice to ensure that gas is
produced safely, and that our environment is protected'

Page 62

https://action.bcndp.ca/page/-/bcndp/docs/BC-NDP-Platform-2017.pdf

As someone who works in the industry, I can tell you that hydraulic fracturing and LNG are mutually inclusive.  You cannot have one without the other.

So NDP, are you for or against the natural gas industry?  You can't sit on the fence forever.  The voters in BC have a right to know, so when we go back to the polls we know who to (or not to) vote for.  You need to be open and honest with the voters on this issue.

Comment: To quote the author, this article is crapola!  Jones arrogantly writes "As a refresher, the equalization system was set up to ensure Canadians receive roughly equal levels of public services regardless of the province in which they live."

Well, lets review some facts: 
- Quebec has massively less expensive University Education for Quebecers and People from France. If other Canadians want to attend those Universities, the govt increases the price by a factor 1,000% or more.
-Quebec has public daycare that is a fraction of the price of Ontario day cares and is publicly subsidized. (I cannot speak to day care prices in other provinces).

These are two examples where Equalization Payments and the Equalization System subsidize Quebec to ensure its citizens receive a higher level of public service then other Canadians - by using tax payer dollars from other Canadians not just Quebecers.

Not Quebec bashing, they have leveraged the system to their benefit.  Equalization formula is broken.

Comment: Most of us are not against paying taxes. But as a single childless person, I pay and receive few benefits. I ride to work, haven't been to a doctor and dentist in years, etc. And that is fine, we all need a helping hand, I am not against medical care, or free education or even subsidised childcare.

What I see is wasteful spending on frivolous special interests that don't actually solve any problems, rather just keep the problems stewing to give beaurocrates and charities work...aka create work programs.

I think the total tax rate for any person ( Income,sales, property, etc) should not pass 49% but I believe that ALL income should have to be reported (overseas money, RE, all capital gains,etc)....but we should all pay less tax. I also belive in a progressive stepped system. Just why should Overtime be penalised at the highest marginal rate, whilst the first tax bracket is so low? People who work hard an earn more tend to pay a disproportionate amount of tax.

Comment: You make a good point about the nuclear option causing more severe political polarization.  If it takes a super majority to confirm a presidential appointee, then that should theoretically force presidents to nominate moderates capable of garnering at least some bipartisan support - something that any American should be able to see as a good thing.  It is quite disingenuous to lay the blame for the nuclear option solely on Harry Reid and the Democrats though.  It was the Republicans, and particularly Mitch McConnell who really broke the system by promising, and then carrying out the promise to block ALL Obama nominees, regardless of where they fell on the ideological spectrum.  The blocking of Merrick Garland is an excellent case in point, as I think almost any Republican would agree that he was quite moderate, qualified, and even acceptable to Republicans, and they blocked him simply because they could. It was Republicans who broke the system through their tactic of total obstruction.

Comment: What we need is rent control, and legislation that does more to enforce construction of affordable rental units. We also need to get over our version of how single family housing should work going forward. Two cars per family and detached homes are not realistic in a city where some kind of concerted push will probably take ten years just to normalize the rental market for people who only need one bedroom.

It's going to take the implementation of some very unpopular regulations to force landlords and investment construction firms to create affordable housing out of cheaply made, badly laid out high rise condos they can expect to sell for far in excess of their value. They'll argue any regulatory obligations anathema to business interests, and Vancouver will fall into the sea if we cross them. That's a big enough problem for this decade. But If people expect to have the whole ten yards- the garage, the big yard, they need to go to places like Surrey or Coquitlam where the land is.

Comment: Not a big believer in polls, but ...in general, immigration is needed in this relative small country.  Particularly if you believe in the aging demographic stats.

However, the WAY in which immigration is conducted needs to change.  Canada has several problems (immigration being one).  The others are a small population which limit scale, a concentrated population, which leads to real estate troubles, etc.   

Here's a way to fix it all in one package - set immigration based on location.   Since Canada already has a "points system", need to add to it.  Canada will direct WHERE new immigrants must settle, at least until they get their full citizenship.  So the population may be better balanced.  Places like Northern Ontario, Manitoba, Sask, Eastern Canada, etc. can use more people and create bigger markets.   This will help with our other problems.

This is not a big price to pay for a chance to live in the best county of the world!

Comment: In Ontario, section 147 of the Highway Traffic Act (HTA) says any “vehicle travelling upon a roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic at that time and place shall, where practicable, be driven in the right-hand lane.  Normal doesn’t mean the speed of other traffic. It means the speed limit, according to the Ontario Provincial Police. The speed limit is the maximum speed at which vehicles should be travelling, i.e. 100 KPH. So, if someone else is at 130 KPH the speed limit is still 100 not 130. This also applies to HOV lanes. The Minister of Transport also stated this under questioning in the Legislative Assembly. The law needs to be changed and  then maybe we'll have a little less road rage. The solution, privatised photo-radar everywhere, especially around schools. The province gets a percentage of the fines as do other drivers clustered around the offender when the photo is taken. Motorist share can be put in an MTO account to offset the cost of plate renewals. Let fools pay.

Comment: I agree a change is needed, but to what? 
A system where MPs are beholden to their parties (closed list proportional)? 
A system that creates permanent minorities (straight proportional with no cut-off points)? 
A system where someone can cast a "moral" vote that does not count (ranked ballots)? 
A system where some people have more representative voting than others (rural-urban votes)? 
A system deemed too complicated (single transferable ballot)? 
A system requiring multiple ballots (various regional mixed-member proportional representation systems)?

We need to work on the replacement system, not just make a random decision on what the replacement should be.

Comment: Mr. Canner clearly has a background in law, not economics, or a willful ignorance of the latter. We’ve been over this before, but it’s worth getting him up to speed.

The issue is purely supply and demand. There are fewer major college coaching jobs than there are university professor jobs, and fewer qualified and desired candidates for those coaching jobs than there are qualified and desired candidates for professor jobs. The market price for the rare supply typically rises higher than the market price for the abundant supply.

Additional factors include anticipated replacement cost – that is, if Mike McIntyre were to leave, the cost to bring in a comparable replacement – and the perceived value he brings to the university. There are higher priced coaches, all at higher profile football programs, and lower priced coaches at lower profile programs. 


It’s a simple reality that has nothing to do with “priorities”.

If a Canadian is awaiting trial, in a foreign jail, or was convicted, after a fair trial, there is little cause for a Canadian diplomat to try to help them. Even the guilty need a fair trial, and Omar really may be innocent.

Comment: Proportional representation could be a solution to our democracy's corrupting, despotic concentration of power. Political writers have perceived the limits of power any person or body can have to be the foundation of a free society. I was introduced to the importance of the limits to power in Montesquieu's The Spirit of the Laws and later in the political writings of writers like John Locke.

First past the post is a system that can give established political parties majorities, with near absolute power, with a little over one third of the popular vote. We must also consider the other side of the equation. New parties, which can be a response to abuses by established parties, can get over ten percent of the popular vote and win no seats. First past the post shuts out new political movements, giving established parties a despotic stranglehold on power.

Comment: In painting DACA as a flagrant disregard for our constitutional separation of powers, Sessions exhibited a fundamental misunderstanding of what DACA did.
The program was based on the well-established executive-branch authority to exercise prosecutorial discretion in setting enforcement priorities.
Rather than grant legal status, DACA simply deferred enforcement action against immigrants who met certain qualifications and permitted them to work lawfully in the meantime.
And despite Sessions’s suggestion that President Barack Obama departed from established precedent in creating DACA, the practice of granting deferred action has been formally recognized as within the executive branch’s authority since the Reagan administration.
http://tinyurl.com/ybc6cf9e

Comment: Fine volcanic particulates and aerosols injected into the stratosphere by large eruptions cause short-term (several months to years) *cooling* because they reflect some incoming sunlight back to space.

As far as greenhouse gases, all volcanic activity on Earth (on land and under the oceans) releases less than 1% of the CO2 generated by human activities. The CO2 released during the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo, the second most powerful of the 20th century, released as much CO2 as the world's road vehicles do in a week.

Comment: The problem with direct Chinese investment in Canadian corporations , is that direct investment is not a reciprocal arrangement between countries. Until this changes I think allowing Chinese direct investment in Canada will be seen as a mistake in future years.

Comment: No one is entitled to a dividend.    The PF was created to save excess revenue from oil extraction to pay for serices when oil revenue was no longer sufficient to cover those expenses.   The PFD was a neat way to ensure citizens stayed engaged in the process and also share in the excess revenue.   It provided economic stimulus once per year which was nice.   There is no longer excess revenue to share.   Accordingly, the PF needs to be used solely for its primary and intended pupose which is to fund state services.    It is not, and was never intended to be an annuity for individuals simply because they lived here 12 straight months.   The "people" referred to in the consitution and statutes is a collective term.  It includes us and future citizens and the fund should be used in a manner that serves this generation and future generations.    If eliminating the PFD means that income and sales taxes are kept low and affordable, then the "people" present and future are benefitted.

Comment: The Scarborough RT is being dismantled because its capacity (4,000 pphpd, max. people/hour) is woefully inadequate — right now, 4,600 pphpd are cramming it at rush hour. And because it's orphaned technology which never caught on, for which we can't get replacement parts. It's even artificially slowed down to minimize breakdowns in its remaining years.

The LRT is standard technology successfully used around the world, supported by several vendors; the total opposite of the orphaned RT. And with a capacity of 15,000 pphpd, it would comfortably serve commuters for several generations. Plus, its low cost leaves billions available to build even more rapid transit across Scarborough — as of now, similar money would bring Scarborough either 1 stop (subway), or 24 stops (LRT) on two full lines.

Comment: PERS has been reformed (benefits reduced) over 20 times since 1995. PERS is a red herring that distracts from the real issue: Oregon needs fundamental reform of its revenue structure and clear analysis of its spending needs. PERS is one element in a much larger system, most of which has gone through nothing like the review or reform that PERS has gone through. But the idea that Oregon is "in default" or that there are not systemic issues to be addressed--that will get us nowhere. We need to be sober and persevering and honest to succeed at real reform. There are no especially easy answers. Measure 97 failed--the corporations turned out to have very deep pockets--but we need something of that order, more finely tuned, to address the larger issues we must take on.

Comment: "Merkel's open door policy, while warm-hearted was demonstrably foolish and untenable in the real world."

I think it's you that isn't living in the world that Germany was facing. The extraordinary refugee crisis in 2015 saw hundreds of thousands of refugees at the borders of Germany and several other eastern European countries. Short of stationing soldiers along every inch of their border, or building a New Berlin Wall, Germany had two choices. Take in refugees in an orderly way, documenting them as they came, or have their country over-run by unknown persons. They wisely chose the former. 

The real world doesn't lend itself to pat answers and hysterical xenophobia. The facts are that Germany is a highly developed country and a very safe place to live. This terrible crime doesn't change that in any significant way.

Comment: From a large health insurer— Neither Republicans nor Democrats face up to the fact that broad private health insurance for Americans will be too expensive for most Americans without large government subsidy. Most Americans meaning the middle class and not just the poor. Half of all Americans already receive insurance at work which is subsidized by Federal tax benefits received by employers and by employees. The last Republican plan voted on by the Senate plan provided Federal single payer coverage for pre-existing conditions.  If we cut government subsidies, and cut insurance coverage requirements to enable insurance pricing "at market" it will mean millions of Americans will go uncovered for many medical conditions which will lead to disease and death. Consider that the market price for insurance for someone with cancer or other diseases could be $50,000 to $100,000 per year. We need single payer insurance backed by private insurance like most major countries have.

Comment: The truth is no union really wants to go on strike for a variety of reasons. Without the right to strike contract negotiations are simply a pantomime of a cap in hand. Whenever I see a strike, knowing of the many factors that can lead to a complete collapse of the union or the strike, and see a workforce standing together long enough to march on the picket line I know there is something up with management which is causing the worker dissatisfaction. Comment: Yet again, the editors ram into the "news" section (roll eyes) yet ANOTHER article that belongs in the opinion and editorial section.

Hello editors, could you please stop doing that?

Look, if you pull out your college notes from the course "Journalism 101", it really is not that difficult to grasp. An article of opinion goes on the editorial page. A straight news report goes on the news page.

An example of how you failed today:

"Sensing weakness in the U.S.-led liberal democratic order, China is stepping forward with detailed plans to defuse tensions on the Korean peninsula, bring wealth to Africa... "

Whoa, stop right there.

China plans to "bring wealth to Africa"?

What?!

Look, that is a fine OPINION, one doubtlessly broadcast by the publicity arm of the Chinese government.

But an equally fine opinion is this: "China is stepping forward to position itself to gain more access to, and exploit, resources in Africa for the benefit of China".

Stop ramming opinion in news reports.

Comment: Of course defence lawyers deliberately delay proceedings.  Anyone who thinks otherwise is naive.  Delay is defence counsels' strongest ally.  Witnesses move away, die, can't be located, change their mind about testifying or otherwise become unavailable.  Those who remain are subject to the same phenomenon as all of us:  with the passage of time memories fade, become less precise, less certain and therefore more vulnerable on cross-examination.

That said, is deliberate delay actually an improper defence tactic?  After all, it merely plays on an evidentiary characteristic of our adversarial trial system:  the reliability or vulnerability of witnesses.

What the SCC seems to be saying here, in effect, is that some amount of deliberate delay is permissible, that trial judges have the ability to control it through their interlocutory orders, and that if  counsel still refuse to rein it in, then the trial judge can penalize them personally with an award of costs.  What's the problem?

Comment: Much of the impact of the USFWS regulation would have been upon ordinary hunting methods and means, not, strictly speaking, "predator control."  Some of these methods and means had become, in recent years, more aggressive in targeting predators, using practices considered marginally ethical in other times. 

And it continues. Recently, the Board of Game considered a proposal to allow same-day airborne land and shoot of wolves in several interior region units, under a trapping license. The proposal could not pass under current state law, but it represents a troubling thought trend. Were there data supporting overpopulation of predators or a direct relationship between higher predator numbers and lower numbers of ungulates?  No. And yet, the Board seemed intrigued.

It is time for Alaskans to become more interested in the sorts of practices being considered by our state regulators, if we are so proud of how well we manage.

Comment: Avoid creating subsidies for electric vehicles--as an immediate policy, even better idea!  Incentives, like any government grants/programming, are hard to kill once they have been implemented.

What are these enormous subsidies for gasoline fueled vehicles? Certainly not $8,000 (in Quebec) or $14,000 (in Ontario) per vehicle.  Near as I can tell, most of the so-called subsidies for gasoline-fueled vehicles is actually about costing environmental damage, health costs, etc. on the basis that the consumer purchase price doesn't factor in these post-purchase "costs".   Using the same logic, then cigarettes, fast food, booze, TV and internet....well, everything, for that matter, is being subsidized because the purchase price doesn't consider post-purchase "costs".  

Subsidies for EV's are an inefficient and expensive way to achieve carbon reduction, and the subsidies tend to end up in the pockets of the already-affluent.   It's bad policy.

Comment: It's the fundamental duty of all governments to protect everyone within their borders. By doing so all governments maintain and justify their sovereignty. The only situation that triggers our responsibility to protect (R2P) in a foreign land, is when their own government commits human rights abuses against them on a mass scale. The foreign government is violating its duty, and therefore can no longer claim authority. This is what justifies intervention, including military intervention if necessary, in a humanitarian crisis.

The crisis in Myanmar is fundamentally different than Yugoslavia, Iraq and Libya. In those cases abuses occurred, but no where near the level that would trigger R2P. The Myanmar government however is in the act of committing a real crime against humanity. The scale is massive, currently impacting 400,000 people with the numbers rising rapidly. Our responsibility to protect those people is thereby invoked.

Comment: While I concur with most of your comments, I'm not sure that the union is correct in adding to the costs. Adding more costs to the running of colleges will just increase tuition costs for the students. I, too, teach at a college part-time, and marking and other time is covered by the hourly classroom teaching amount. The college uses an informal ratio of two or three hours for every hour in the classroom for part-timers. The issue though is with full-time faculty, they are well paid for what they do. I've done the math, and the full-timers receive, when compared on an hourly basis, way more than the part-timers, as well as, they have benefits, a pension, and lots of time off. Administration  and full-time faculty costs are very high, and those costs should be examined, with the goal of keeping tuition manageable for our students. Many have to rely on OSAP. So, costs to run the colleges are high, and many students then incur debt to the government to pay for their education. Hmmm...

Comment: Island Air only had like a 5% to 7% market share, so essentially Island Air is a non factor in SW's decision.  SW would have to commit at least  10 to 12 aircraft (Boeing 737s) to go head to head with HAL.  HAL has 20 Boeing 717s for their interisland routes, but I think they only use 14 of them for normal operations.  SW would also have to devote capital for a maintenance hanger, maintenance equipment, maintenance, ground and gate personnel, and gate and counter space.  So I think the investment is in the range of $750 million to enter into the interisland market that has not been hugely profitable even for HAL.  I just think for SW there are other longer range more profitable routes to be taken  versus a limited short range interisland market.

Comment: While this is both very noble and macroeconomically desirable, there are consequences which need to be foreseen and countered, otherwise there will be a nasty right wing populist backlash. Specifically, housing and education come under pressure. A good example is New Zealand, where immigration in recent years has been twice Canada's rate (1.5% as opposed to 0.7% of population annually). There, housing is even harder to acquire than in Canada, with a similar price bubble and confusion regarding foreign capital. The new left-green-nationalist coalition government has vowed to reduce immigration and to stop foreign purchases of existing housing. For Canada, clearly much more must be done to stabilise the housing market for the long term, without making it harder for people to buy their first property.  The distortions of low interest rates and neoliberal policies need to be corrected if newcomers are to be successfully integrated.

Comment: I love all the banter of righteous people claiming we need our "Fair share and receive maximum benefits from development of our natural resources..." and then there is deafening silence when it comes to our fair share on fish taxes. 

Commercial fisheries (private industry) harvests more than 99 percent of a public resource, which is about 6 billion pounds of seafood, valued at $6 billion. 

The state only taxes the exvessel value - or about $1.8 billion. Is that fair? 

The fish tax revenue does not generate enough revenue to even cover the cost of commercial fish management - the state has to use $25 million per year to subsidize the cost to manage this private industry. Is that fair?

$4 billion in export seafood value is not taxed by Alaska. This is the seafood processor value that leaves the state - primarily to Seattle. Not taxed. Zero. No benefit to the average Alaskan. Is that fair? 

There is no royalty on fish taken by commercial fisheries - Is that fair?

Comment: If you are referring to the Pontifical Scripture Commission, they have no Magesterial authority.  They can only report the conclusions of their research.  No theologian has Masgesterial authority.  Theologians are more like lawyers--in the sense that they argue their case.  They do not have the final word on the case, however.  That authority lies with the judge.  In this case the pope and bishops are like the judges.  They are the ones who make a definitive decision regarding what the theologians have reported.  

The Church at ecumenical council and or the pope when he defines something are like the Supreme Court. Once the Church has spoken, the case is closed.  In the case of women priests, it might be arguable whether JPII issued a papal definition of a doctrine.  What is not arguable is that the teaching is infallible.  In other words--JPII likely just reiterated what the Church has always believed.

Comment: Thank you for your comment semarumi.  I am sorry I could not find the quote on the links you provided.  However, I can assure you there is no arrogance.  We rely on hydrologists all the time for advice, and meteorologists for weather predictions.  There is not always an agreed view from the experts.  I was not in the meetings you refer to with the City of Cape Town.  But in 2013/14 we had a near record rainfall year, and in 2014 the dams were overflowing, while we experienced electricity load-shedding.  That is where our attention had to be  --  and after the drier 2015, we had expert predictions that things would improve in 2016.  And again in 2017. We had clear memories of having to mothball the very expensive desalinator in Mossel Bay because the rains came again.  And in any case, the national Department had run out of money for major infrastructure, so we could not have commissioned another desalinator anyway.

Comment: This. Yes.

I am in the business school and the offers we make to rookies (i.e. new PhD graduates) is the same regardless of their gender. But then the salary remains pretty much fixed (apart from the union raises now) until you make tenure. However, rookie salaries keep going up due to market forces, we have to compete with other schools to hire rookies. But we don't have to compete with other schools to retain existing faculty, unless of course, that faculty member goes out and gets a job offer that we then have to match (or beat!). I was hired 5 years ago. We just made an offer to a rookie that is higher than my salary. I have 5 years more experience and more publications, yet I make less. It's not because of gender. It's because I will only get a raise when I get tenure or if I get another offer from another school. This system does create problems where more senior, more accomplished faculty get paid less than rookies, but it definitely is NOT gender discrimination.

Comment: This is incomplete analysis. 

Overheads can be estimated for each specialization by region with a little research.

Compensation affects the capacity of - any - profession to deliver quality of service.

Dental offices can do X-rays, anaesthesia, sutures, day surgery etc.

Family physicians refuse to suture, will not set simple fractures, and do not have any X-ray facility. 

Therefore, patients overload ERs for routine cases causing long wait times.

The other major problem with the Canadian system is that most professionals have to go through 4 years of wasteful undergrad, rather than being accepted directly from high school into an integrated Co-op program.

Extra undergrad contributes to student uncertainty, increases student debt, decreases working years, and makes no contribution to the skill of the practitioner.

Comment: Frau Merkel's comments are understandable bluster in an election year, when, like so many politicians, she has to account to an electorate that wants more than it is willing to pay for.

Germany has a good gig going.  Effective control of the Euro has allowed the country to build an export dynamo at the expense of its poorer neighbours, and to hold the deep pocket cards as the inevitable conflicts unfold.  

But much of that deep pocket act is a direct result of Germany pulling the short-arm act with respect to military spending commitments for NATO members.

Trump has very reasonably asked NATO members to step up to fair sharing of the costs of maintaining the world's most successful and long lasting military alliance.  Germany is a wealthy country that has not only welched on its commitments, but also leverages the NATO security blanket for its own domestic economic benefit.

When German thinkers accuse America of not being trustworthy, the irony is a bit much.

Comment: Believability is not the proper litmus test. If it were, all novels would be true, since they are usually believable. In this particular case the former MI6 officer claims to have covert knowledge of Putin's intimate discussions right inside the Kremlin. How could a former intelligence officer, with no organizational support, possibly have access to Putin's private conversations? Comment: You simply don't understand what "hate speech" is, John.   Nor do you understand the precise legal definition of free speech.

Listen closely:

The ONLY speech that is banned by law is speech that calls for or incites imminent violence.

What Milo has to say doesn't fit into that category.  Not even close.  He has never in any way advocated violence.

Therefore, his rights to speech fall under the 1st Amendment.  They are protected by law.

People can protest his speech, BUT THEY DO NOT HAVE A RIGHT TO USE VIOLENCE TO STOP HIS SPEECH, simply because they don't like what he has to say.

What I'm describing here is free speech 101.

The same rights that (are supposed to) protect Milo are supposed to protect the rest of us, ie you and me, all Catholics, everyone.

Labeling opinions you don't like as "hate speech" and claiming this give you the right to stop others from speaking is against the law.  It's un-Constitutional.

Comment: Since well before Confederation, too many from communities longer settled in Canada have viewed newcomers from exotic countries as a threat.  Wave after wave of newcomers viewed in this manner (and too often faced hostility and discrimination) but their descendants now form the many pillars of our society.

It's natural for newcomers to seek the support, understanding and companionship to be found in communities of people of their own faith and cultural practices but integration with the larger community soon follows by the second generation (while, at the same time, the larger community is enriched by the cultural input from new sources).

For all concerned, the challenges and complexities of the transformation of both the larger society and new Canadians can cause setbacks but in the large majority of cases these are outbalanced by many benefits over time.

Comment: For many in Canada who see a changing climate as a serious problem, a carbon tax is a necessary evil.

But does a carbon tax have anything to do with climate science? Or does a carbon tax fall in the realm of the political?

The answer to that question is more of the latter than the former.

This political fact becomes even more apparent when one compares the core organizing principles of these two ideologies of Carbonism and Communism. While Communism seeks to marshal or harness the economic and political power of the nation-state by organizing through the idea of the worker. Carbonism although similarly structured, takes the organizing principle to the next level – first by substituting the nation-state for the world, and then by directly linking the combined economic and political power of each individual in the world, to the carbon footprint each creates in the world. And in the global context of Carbonism, this individual can either be a person, corporation or business.

Comment: The Internet has global reach but all services must obey all laws of all countries the services are offered. This apply to both the Internet technical infrastructure and all services and access attached to it. 

So a web service must be configured to comply with the laws of each country. In this case if Google does not comply with the Canadian court on blocking the website globally then the court can go to 1) each country court and request it to act, 2) international regulators of the Internet such as those that manage domain names, AS numbers and filters. 

The EU just imposed some $3 billion in fines to Google for giving preferential treatments to searches. This is illegal in the EU, but apparently not so in the U.S. Comply with EU laws or get out. Similarly, Google and other big U.S. webs have been blocked in China. Until they comply with its laws.

Comment: Canadians shouldn't think that the dark undercurrents at play on the political stages in the countries discussed in this article are not at play in Canada.  Under our first-past-the-post electoral system, it is difficult for a charismatic demagogue to emerge as a significant player in Federal politics by rallying an anxious, angry, outcast following with a message that scapegoats foreigners and minorities. Is isn't that Canada doesn't have such anxious, angry, outcasts and wannabe demagogic leaders; only that it is very difficult for Parties focussed upon these features to gain the more than 20% electorate support that is needed here to become a real player for power.

By contrast, under a proportional representation or certain ranked ballot electoral systems like those in the countries discussed in this article,  10% or so support however scattered across a country makes such a Party a player and 20% or more makes it a contender for real power.

Comment: No. Drop us out of Paris accord. It does no good. 
Instead, America needs to put a tax on all consumed goods (both local made and imported)/services, based on where the worst part/service comes from.
With this approach, America can make use of a true weakness of ours (importing way too much), and turn it into a strength. Most importantly, it puts EVERY NATION on an equal footing if done right. 

First we need to do measurements with satellites, specifically, OCO-3. It may not be fully accurate, BUT, it will be precise. IOW, it will measure all nations in the same way.
Secondly, we normalize it based on emissions / $ GDP, not per capita. By going after emissions / $GDP, it will either force state/national gov to lower emissions, OR businesses will simply move out to nations that have lower emissions. That will drop their export, which will then lower their energy needs, and emissions.

Comment: I've been doing HIIT for several years - it is extremely effective and there is a great sense of community at the gym.  I don't do paleo, I generally eat whatever I want, although my diet does lean towards more protein (not necessarily meat) and less carbs.

Society has swung too far the other way - sedentary, overworked, overfed.  That is the truly joyless condition that we need to change.

Comment: An excellent letter from Ursula Retherford. Despite what some property investors and Airbnb wants us to believe, the purpose of residential zoning is to provide homes for residents. not hotel rooms for tourists. If Oahu had an overabundance of homes and not enough residents to fill them, than maybe we could talk about some type of permitting of vacation rentals in residential zoning. But Oahu is facing the exact opposite. Oahu will be short 22,000-28,000 homes in 5-10 years. There are currently 6,000 - 10,000 illegal vacation rentals and the number is growing every day. The City Council needs to pass resolution 17-52 (improve enforcement tools) and shut down the illegal operators and deter others from breaking the law!

Comment: Agree that for most CEO's their impact on the company accounts for no more than 10% of the performance of the business, and they should be paid accordingly.  But others, like Steve Jobs, Jeff Bezos, and closer to home former CP CEO Hunter Harrison, can have a huge impact on the share prices of the companies they run.  And they should be paid way more.  

In the sports analogy, it is not the $25m paid to Lebron James that is offensive.  It is the $9m per year paid to a journeyman benchwarmer who plays 15 minutes a game and averages 6.2 points and 2 rebounds.  For every Lebron there are 200 of those guys, and for every Jobs or Bezos there are probably 1000 guys who play it safe and just collect a big check until retirement.

And what is wrong with both systems is that when Lebron gets a raise to $35m, which is justifiable, the impact will trickle down to the benchwarmer is now somehow magically worth $12m.

Comment: Rail is an investment in a future with adequate mass transit along the urban core of Honolulu where much future growth will take place. It will also prevent urban sprawl which is not a solution to traffic congestion.

We are already short of housing so development along the rail route will fill that need. Another need is economic growth through investment that will increase city revenue and help pay for rail operations and construction. The increase in the surcharge revenue will pay for construction as well.

With economic growth comes economic diversification, and will also bring in more revenue through the surcharge for construction needs.

Finally not having urban sprawl.... priceless.

Comment: The biggest economic problem of the 21st century will be low growth.  Excellent book on the topic: Capital in the 21st Century,

The gap between the poor and wealthy will rapidly increase as GDP decreases.  This is because wealthy holders of capital will be able to almost always earn higher returns on their capital than 2% GDP, for example.  Their gains will quickly add up and multiply and governments will not be able to keep up with social programs to mitigate the increasing number of poor people in our society.

Neither side of the immigration debate will solve the low growth problem: 
- Decrease immigration so that existing citizens will have more jobs.  However, businesses  must have more consumers, otherwise there will be no job increases, for anyone.

-Increase immigration so that there will be more consumers.  However immigrants will compete for employment, especially at the lower wage jobs and will bring us some costs to integrate them into society in initial years.

Comment: Finally, some sense. The issue isn't that every institution's gender mix should match that of society. The issue is whether people are being discriminated against based on gender. We can't claim sexism if we look only at the employee gender mix without looking at the gender mix of job applicants. 
All of the preceding also applies to race, of course. 
The debate over gender-based brain differences is actually moot. Any differences that are identified are in gender averages. Individuals vary greatly on any measure and may or may not be typical of their gender. Let's not fall into a "scientific" tyranny of expectations based on group averages. We must treat each person as an individual and let that person develop their abilities and follow their interests without prejudging where they fit.

Comment: We, as a country are not in new territory with regard to an attempt to influence a US National Election through illegal means: the last occurrence of this type was in 1972 during an event we know as "Watergate."

As with Watergate, this latest occurrence involved the electronic infiltration of organizations involved in our electoral process.

We need to be patient with the various US Law Enforcement Agencies and Congress while they conduct their investigations.

If it is determined that a Head of State or persons acting at the behest of a Head of State, as it was with Watergate, were involved with the 2016 attempt, then our nation must act with the same determination and resolve to bring that Head of State down and to bring all persons involved to justice, as we did in 1972.

The nationality of the persons who may have committed such acts are not important; their behavior and our determination to prevent further occurrences is all that matters.

Lets be patient and support the process.

Comment: The man had nothing in his possession.  He WAS considering purchasing a chainsaw with accessories but decided to get another model - he RETURNED the first chainsaw to customer service.

*Arresting and detaining are NOT the same thing.  The Police are responsible for detaining.

Charges should absolutely be laid against the store manager.  He committed a criminal offence by assaulting the man, and likely several misdemeanors for harassment.  In addition, the accosted man should sue in civil court.

Comment: It seems to me that the bank economists have issued a timely warning. Across Canada, most housing markets currently are not overvalued: houses in these regions are still more affordable than historical averages  based on measures of affordability that use discounted (vs. posted) mortgage rates (e..g Bank of Canada housing index). Comment: Section 13.1 was like section 14 of the Sask. Human Rights Code, dealt with by the Supreme Court of Canada in 2013.  The Court interpreted the provision strictly, but upheld it as constitutional.  Here's what it said about the topic:

"Hate speech is an effort to marginalize individuals based on their membership in a group.  Using expression that exposes the group to hatred, hate speech seeks to delegitimize group members in the eyes of the majority, reducing their social standing and acceptance within society.  Hate speech, therefore, rises beyond causing distress to individual group members.  It can have a societal impact.  Hate speech lays the groundwork for later, broad attacks on vulnerable groups that can range from discrimination, to ostracism, segregation, deportation, violence and, in the most extreme cases, to genocide."

Groups like "stormfront, summerfront, or what ever front" - and their followers - practiced that kind of hate speech, and that's what section 13 combatted.

Comment: Thanks for highlighting the hard work that goes into the success of family owned businesses. My wife and I have spent over 20 years building our business. We worked day & night - literally, to make sure our clients had the service they needed. We employ staff, offer benefits and pay our taxes. We play by the ever changing rule book laid out by the government. Now, in the name of "fairness", the government wants more of our hard earned money. Where is the fairness in government employees having indexed pensions, double dipping and more? Mr. Morneau is supposedly seeking input before moving forward with his proposed tax changes - we haven't been contacted. Business owners are not the evil doers that Mr. Trudeau and Mr. Morneau make us out to be. We are the people who actually create jobs and keep Canadians working.

Comment: As always, the financial decision should come down to where the individual can achieve the best after-tax return on their money commensurate with the amount of risk taken. While the mortgage paydown offers a rather low rate of return, it is also guaranteed to lower one's indebtedness. One could reasonably expect to achieve a higher rate of return over the long term by investing in equities in a registered account but that is not guaranteed. If the individual is a no-risk, nervous Nellie type, then paying down the mortgage vs. buying GICs in a registered account makes sense. 
This type of person, should they own equities, is likely to panic when the next decline takes hold and lose money so again, the pay down the mortgage option would be right for them.  The answer may be just the opposite for the more experienced investor who has shown the ability to handle market volatility in the past. 
Know who you are. Money decisions are not always made rationally. Sometimes emotions take over.

Comment: A decent editorial were it not for the penultimate paragraph equating Khadr with Arar. The differences are huge. Arar was completely innocent; moreover it was an overt negligent act of the Canadian government that led to his rendition and torture.

The refusal of the Harper government to intervene was indifferent if not callous but it was not negligent. The federal government retains the prerogative power over foreign affairs and the SCC acknowledged that it was under no compulsion to seek Khadr's return. 

Khadr's rights were violated only insofar as the manner in which he was interviewed by Canada while in U.S. custody. For that Khadr's lawyers were seeking $20 million. Trudeau's decision to settle for half that might be legally sound but I fear politically naive. Given the extent to which even 'reasonable people' are conflicted on this issue, it would have been wiser to let the courts prescribe the level of compensation due Khadr and to offer a precise explanation for that remedy.

Comment: Perhaps because the international agreements Canada has signed and passed into domestic law under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and regulations make it clear that they are not committing a crime if they are a refugee?  See s. 133 IRPA.

One of the primary requirements to claim refugee status is that one is outside their country of citizenship or habitual residence. s. 96 IRPA so most refugee claimants do not have legal status even those in camps or those who have entered Canada.

 Per s. 99 (1) A claim for refugee protection may be made in or outside Canada.

Comment: Of course there won't be any development when oil is around 50.00 or less per barrel. It wouldn't be economically feasible; however, leasing and exploration for oil and gas resources in the Arctic is a long-term process, and even if one were to find large reserves in the ground, it would be decades before anything could go into production. Over the next 10 or 15 years there's a good chance we'll see 140.00 per barrel oil again.   As for the spill response, it would all depend on a case by case basis. For instance a spill that occurred over the top of a sold, 8 foot thick sheet of ice could easily be cleaned up, while one under the ice would be more problematic. The point is that just blabbing on and on, and on about an inability to clean up spilled oil isn't exactly honest, in fact is a dumbed-down oversimplification of the process that ignores the details that may or may not arise on a case by case basis. It's not all the same.

In Texas, for instance, a person who steals a car is looking at 6 to 24 months in prison for a first offense. Post SB 91, that person in Alaska couldn't get a day of jail time.

The only state that did anything comparable to Alaska was California -- and that effort is pretty universally considered almost as big a failure as SB 91.

Comment: What's the "wow" for, Don417? Jeff's comment makes perfect sense. 
Owning my own business allowed me to do what I loved, to make my own decisions about what I did and how I did it. It allowed me to use my skills and hone them further. AND I took advantage of tax laws ("tax loopholes") that benefited me. BUT! No pension, no medical/dental coverage. No "employer" contributions to anything unless I ponied them up myself. I paid for sick day and vacation time--in fact, being sick penalized me further--couldn't sell anything!

One day, doing contract work for a BC govt. Ministry, talked to a BCGEU employee who was very nervous about impending strike action. She had it all figured out: union gave her this, she could do that and--If the strike didn't last too long--lose NO income while she was off work. I gave her my story about sick days, vacations; said if I stopped work--I stopped earning. The blank stare she gave me was priceless. She had absolutely no clue. 

But I never complained.

Comment: Bryan is correct, you can't kill the rumen bacteria without causing major problems.  And the cited UN/FAO report is inaccurate and needs  a rewrite.  Most methane contribution from livestock comes from anaerobic conditions in  manure slurry pits-  all of which should be attributed to agribusiness practices and not to the livestock themselves. The reason a grass-based diet produces more methane is that the grain-based agribusiness cow bypasses her feed past the rumen,  where the normal cellulose digestion takes place.  Growing that grain however has a huge climate-changing footprint, not only from the fossil fuel to grow it but from plowing which releases masses of carbon.  (This has gotten a huge amount of research interest lately and deserves its own column.)  Cattle on grass, properly managed, are no more a threat to the climate than are moose or any other herbivore.  See www.real-food.com/commentary  for more information.  Thank you.

Comment: That's not actually a thing.  What you're talking about with the car is the doctrine of replevin, which allows the owner of stolen property to recover it.  It's subject to a host of limitations, including the fact that it doesn't apply to money.  There's also exceptions for good faith purchasers which would apply to the stolen car.  Your example is wrong.  If the purchaser of the car didn't know it was stolen (and didn't have reason to suspect that it was), they may actually have a good claim to keep it.  That doctrine gets more complicated than the character limit here will allow, so I'll leave you to look it up.

Generally speaking, it's good to recognize that "the law" is actually a thing which has meaning and effect outside of your individual belief.  The fact that you may wish for a certain thing to be true "as a matter of law" doesn't actually make it so.

Comment: When Pope John Paul allowed the local bishop to authorize (or decline to authorize) the celebration of the Tridentine Mass (Extraordinary Form), the bishop was required to make sure that both the celebrants and the members of the congregation affirmed both the validity and the authority of the Mass of Paul VI (Ordinary Form.) Pope Benedict made what I think history will judge as a serious pastoral error in extending the permission without continuing to protect those values and affirmations. I believe that Pope Francis would correct those mistakes if Benedict were not still living; and that he might yet correct them if Benedict pre-deceases him.
Of more concern than the rite of the EF is the fact that those who celebrate it use a different liturgical calendar and a different lectionary from the rest of the church, both of which are gravely deficient by comparison. I support a wider use of Latin in the OF for those who understand and love the Latin; and also of Gregorian chant.

Comment: Actually, that is untrue. Here is a list of spills of Kinder Morgan's pipeline (compiled by the Wilderness Committee) 1/2

-  July 15, 2005: About 210,000 litres of crude were released into the area surrounding the company's Sumas Mountain storage facility in Abbotsford, making its way into Kilgard Creek.
-  July 24, 2007: An oil spill occurred along the Kinder Morgan pipeline in Burnaby when a construction crew inadvertently hit the unmarked pipe with an excavator. Almost 250,000 litres (about 1500 barrels) of oil shot out of the ground, soaking a residential neighbourhood and seeping into the Burrard Inlet. At least 50 homes had to be evacuated. (See BC MOE's website for more info on this one: http://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/spills-environmental-emergencies/spill-incidents/past-spill-incidents) 
- May 6, 2009: A sizeable spill was discovered at the company's Burnaby Mountain tank farm, with almost 200,000 litres leaking out into the facility.

Comment: Are students allowed to use mechanical aids when they do the provincial maths assessment test in Grades 3, 6 and 10? If not, why not? When I did maths (arithmetic it was called then) 70 years ago, there were no mechanical aids. It was all fingers and memory work. People who worked behind the counter in a grocery store had to do all the calculations for purchases in their head. Now, cash registers do it in a fraction of the time. The important thing is to know how to use a cash register, not how to multiply 7x9 and get 63 using just your memory. Maybe, if computer use was allowed, the test results would vastly improve. That's why more emphasis should be placed on understanding the functions of mathematics rather than bringing back boring repetitious drills and memory work made obsolete in real life by faster and more efficient mechanical aids.

Comment: Been to the following European cities in the past 10 years: London, Copenhagen, Malmo, Tampere, Vienna, Innsbrook, Salzburg, Moscow, St. Petersburg, Zurich, Minsk, Yaroslavl , Helsinki, Frankfurt, Vaxjo. So, what I've noticed is that Europe is a lot older than Canada. 
Having just returned from Copenhagen its refreshing to see all the bikes and the mass of bikes that are parked. Yes there are many dedicated bike lanes, but what stuck out more than anything was the respect drivers had for cyclists. Plus, people ride their bikes in Europe because its what they can afford. And the distances they cover are much less than what we cover in the GTA. 
It drives me nuts when people compare Europe to Canada. Here in the GTA it's a mini war between pedestrians and cyclists and the car/truck. I've never felt that way in Europe. In fact it's the opposite. 
To change attitudes for cyclists and the car will take another 25 years .

In the end, either approach regardless of how you invest in divdend growth stocks is likley to be wildly successful for investors with a reasonable, long-term, investmet timeframe.  

As always, traders or others who have a short term are likely to disagree.

Comment: A sales tax?  The most regressive kind of tax.  To fix PERS?  That's completely nuts!

Oregon Tier One PERS retirees (with their top 1% pensions) are going to suck up a huge slice of government revenue for years to come - until they are no longer drawing pensions.

A generation ago, PERS boards - and elected officials at all levels - made decisions that were dumb as a post and which should have been illegal. But judges (ON PERS) have said that their benefits cannot be reduced.

Therefore, the state population will have to go without needed services for another generation.  And current and future public employees will have to take a hit on their retirements. 

A tax increase is out of the question.

The best solution (ultimately the most decisive and most fair) would be to pass an initiative taking all elected officials - all all levels - out of PERS forever.

Comment: What romantic slop. Those who idealize military service this way stand in the great American tradition of glorifying war.  And, with three exceptions, no American war was ever necessary to "protect our freedom."  The three exceptions were the Revolutionary War, the Civil War, and World War II.  The others were nothing but bullying weaker nations.

I, too, am a combat veteran.  We detested the army but my fellow draftees and I did our jobs well because our lives depended on it.  Most of us made it, though minus a thing here or here: a toe, some skin, our mental equilibrium.  In my case, severe hearing loss.  The worst loss was a good buddy.

Get this through your heads, people: war is mass insanity.  It's not just the killing and dying.  It's that wars take on lives of their own and go on and needlessly on, grinding up lives (civilian as well as military) long after the original objective has been forgotten.  My war was that way, so have Little Bush's proved.  Why are we still there?

Comment: Van Brocklin is not right.  This is an ER Nurse with an injured, unconscious patient.  The nurse has a moral and legal duty to that patient - and this is an ER where she may have had more patients. She must treat/watch-over the patient until death of patient, transfer to a ward, operating room, or ICU - or until the turnover to competent medical personnel is complete and paperwork is done.  Otherwise, she could be fired and lose her license. She has incoming patients. Was she the Charge Nurse? If so, she has yet more responsibilities, legal and moral. On a scale of 1-100, the child having a temper tantrum over a candy bar is nothing. A nurse with legal and moral responsibilities is a 100.  Resolved in 2 hours? How long is 2 hours in an ER? Comment: A "bidding war" is the most overrated phrase in hiring a head coach. "Prized" coaches know they can get the money anywhere they go. If money were the main issue then Texas would have the most dominant program in college football(they average about twice as much revenue as Oregon does on an annual basis).  Remember when Oregon tried "bidding" for elite D-1 head basketball coaches after firing Ernie Kent? Setting aside Altman's success at Oregon, he was at Creighton and not considered a "Tier 1" head coach. Any head football coach coming to Oregon has to embrace the fact there is virtually zero talent in the state year after year or talent in large enough quantities. So recruiting takes on an entirely different approach than say if you are the head coach at USC or UCLA. I agree with the need to clarify the status of the current head coach ASAP but suggesting Oregon can wade into a "bidding war" for an elite head coach ignores more important issues(for most coaches)  far beyond money.

Comment: did some digging and it seems like much to do about nothing

"After the Raid on Dartmouth, Cornwallis issued a proclamation to separate the two populations, by banning the Mi'kmaq from peninsular Nova Scotia. In New England, the British paid their Rangers a bounty for Mi'kmaq scalps, and the French paid the Wabanaki for British scalps.[Note 1] Cornwallis followed New England's example in his proclamation, which offered a bounty for the scalps of Mi'kmaw fighters. The bounty was not effective. Cornwallis increased the bounty dramatically in March 1751, but this increase brought in only one scalp in the next four months...

For more than a year, Cornwallis sought out Mi'kmaq leaders willing to negotiate a peace. On 16 February 1752, hoping to lay the groundwork for a peace treaty, he repealed his 1749 proclamation against the Wabanaki."

Comment: Mr. Wegman,
Your article describes that the vast majority of the people who fly in and out of this airport are wealthy summer folks who are taking advantage of an unnecessary tax payer funded program.  That is not accurate.   Your readers should know that only 20% of the annual total essential air service (EAS) program dollars for this airport are currently subsidizing flights which are flown by just one of our seasonal air carriers that operates between Memorial Day and Labor Day each year.  The other 80% us used to subsidize the three flights in and out of this airport each day for the remainder of the year.  The local people and businesses who benefit from year round air service here most likely do not fit the wealthy demographic that you describe in your article.  The purpose of the EAS program is to connect them and their businesses to the rest of the national air transportation system.  Without EAS, those are the people who would be affected here, much more so than the wealthy.

Comment: No, it's not "nonsense" -because to be "windless night" it has to be windless EVERYWHERE. That hardly ever happens.

Sure it may not be windy in Cape Town tonight, but then it almost certainly is in Port Elizabeth. Or Durban, or Johannesburg.  We have a power-grid spanning the whole country, we already do ship power from Gauteng to the Western Cape when needed. 
A night where there is no wind would require the weather in a dozen different climate zones to all be alike - it can and does happen, but it's extremely rare. I think we average less than 2 windless nights countrywide PER YEAR.

Most nights there are enough places that do have wind, to cover the places that don't. And it's night-time when demand is at it's lowest as well.
The baseload is only needed for those occasions when the total wind where it is blowing can't quite match the demand from the places where it isn't.

Comment: The real issue here is that universities should not be conducting criminal investigations. We have a system set up to do that. That system is designed to provide both the accuser and the accused with established legal rights. In that system, a jury of peers--not university officials--determines guilt or innocence. If the accused is found guilty, he or she can be punished with time in jail, while a university can only expel the guilty. 

Obama administration policies threatened universities with loss of funding is they failed to "get tough" on sexual assault--meaning university officials presiding over these cases knew they could lose money if they found the accused innocent. Juries, on the other hand, are true neutral parties. Also, the accused were denied basic rights, such as the right to cross-examine their accuser. The accused have won numerous cases against universities for denying their rights.

DeVos is doing the right thing.

NRCan has the mandate to monitor and safeguard our natural resources. They are probably best positioned to get the data, analyze it and make sensible projections.

I hope the new regulatory agency will do just that: ensure that our prudent regulations are complied with. As it stands now, many of the OPR safety requirements are not being met. In some cases the non-compliance has existed for decades, not years, and involves some our most vulnerable sites.

Comment: Debt to GDP ratio or balanced budgets may be good economic indicators, however neither speaks to the most important factor in every country and that is living conditions.  Wilkinson and Pickett  came up with a thorough analysis using living conditions based on eleven different health and social problems: physical health, mental health, drug abuse, education, imprisonment, obesity, social mobility, trust and community life, violence, teenage pregnancies, and child well-being. They found,  among developed countries there was no correlation between wealth and living conditions. For example, Japan, an economic basket case, and Sweden tied for top place as the place to live. The US, the wealthiest developed country, was in last place along with Portugal, as a place to live.

There was correlation, unexplained, between income inequality(top 20% income divided by bottom 20% income) and living conditions. The lower the inequality, the better the living conditions. 

That needs exploring.

Comment: The proposal is to enhance the taxation of investment income in a corporation by eliminating the refundable element of the corporate investment tax. 

Basically, when a corporation earns business income it will pay a low rate of tax, so it will start out with more to invest than would a shareholder if the income was issued as a dividend and invested. When the corporation earns investment income, however, this income is taxed at a special high rate (not the regular corporate rate) that is designed to be the same tax rate that an individual would pay on the same investment income. 

The way the law works currently is that a part of this special high tax is refunded when a corporation pays dividends to shareholders. The proposed change is to eliminate the refund, so this income will essentially be taxed twice (once at the high corporate rate and then again as a dividend in the shareholder's hands) which should mimic what would have happened if the shareholder invested it personally.

Comment: The 1% per year property tax levy increase limit can be exceeded at any time by a vote of the people -- that's exactly what the mayor is proposing. The issue is that many would prefer to not have to ask the voters at all. 

It's likely that a flat-rate income tax would be constitutional TODAY -- it's just that those who want an income tax insist on it being "progressive" (higher rates for higher incomes), and it is the progressivity that is unconstitutional (Article VII Section 1: "All taxes shall be uniform upon the same class of property within the territorial limits of the authority levying the tax..."). That could be solved by simply including a high personal exemption. That is, if people actually had the political will to do it, rather than insisting on progressive rates. 

The real question, as the editorial notes, is whether current funds are being spent in ways that really work (the answer is No), and whether the new funds would be spent any better (remains to be seen).

Comment: The headline is a little misleading.   The brake pedal is there and operates the same as brake pedals have always operated.    What they've done is augment the function of the accelerator pedal and the programming which controls the car.  

EV's and hybrids have always utilized re-generative braking.   That's why Toyota faced some safety concerns and headlines because people who were not expecting it thought the car was accelerating under braking - when it was simply the switch from re-generative braking to friction based.     This newer system seems to optimize the re-generative braking function which is good for maximizing range and also great for extending brake life (EV's and hybrids have much better brake life because much of the braking is done using re-generative - so magnetic as opposed to friction based).

Truly getting rid of the brake pedal would be like some electric traction motors.   On these, to brake harder you can flip the motor into reverse and press the accelerator.

Comment: Right. In my experience with adolescent Confirmation, rather than being a graduation into deeper investment in the Church, all too often it effectively becomes a graduation from the Church.

Yes, the ability to deal with ambiguity is the essence of the spiritually mature. That's a lovely sentiment and quite applicable to adult spirituality. But Confirmation is not about adult spirituality and never has been. We have sacraments of vocation (Matrimony and Holy Orders) and the theology of those sacraments reflects adult commitment. Not so with Confirmation.

Okay, it's a bit of an exaggeration to say I don't care which way the bishops go. I do have my preferences, of course. But the bigger point is that what they are doing now is no solution at all. Practically and pastorally speaking, we have a sacrament without a theological home and a lot of young people being deprived of it as a result.

Comment: Consider: 400 MPs, 247 ANC => 153 other parties. But, there were 177 yes votes, which means that at least 24 ANC MPs must have voted for the impeachment. (If any opposition MPs voted no, then it increases the number of ANC MPs who voted yes.) There were 9 abstentions who were probably from the ANC. (Again, if any were from other parties, then that simply increases the number of ANC members who voted yes.)

Now, of the 247 ANC MPs, 2 recently died and 1 is critically injured after a car crash. So that leaves 244 possible ANC votes. But only 198+24+9=231 voted, which leaves another 244-231=13 who did not vote. 

Now here is the kicker. If the 13 who stayed away plus the 9 who abstained had the courage of their convictions to vote yes, then there would have been 199 yes votes (177+9+13) and Zuma would have been impeached by 1 vote!

Comment: I will admit that this is easier to understand in terms of unity of teaching with variety in application, but we are a sacramental church, so unity of practice should be doable. I'm not sure I am up to it, but maybe somebody is.
Take the Eucharist. For 1500+ years it was explained in terms of pre-Christian religious ritual, like sacrifice and altars. The final stage in a sacrifice is the sharing of the victim to enable a distribution of the numinous among the believers.
The same ritual can be reinterpreted from a different perspective. Instead of the sacrifice as explanatory key, the meal can be understood as Christ's purpose. Christ died so that we can share in his life. The concluding communal meal is a more effective key today than the rarely experienced ritual sacrifice, in a Church based on communion.
One event, understood in two ways, can easily become two different ways of experiencing a common practice. I guess i could have just said Extraordinary and ordinary forms coexist.

Comment: Charles, I appreciate having this discussion; though it is tad late.
Prior to Sen. Begich leaving office I informed him, Sen. Murkowski and Rep. Don Young, that the ACA would fail if two very important aspects of the industry weren't contained/regulated; one was the cost of health care delivery and the other was the cost of health care insurance, as the two are intertwined.
To date, even though Sen. Begich is out of office now, I have regularly contacted our congressional delegation informing them that something needs to be done about the aforementioned. 
Well over 60% of healthcare in Alaska is subsidized by the taxpayer; meaning, at least 40% of Alaskans are getting free healthcare at taxpayer expense. Seniors, the working poor, disabled, Alaska Natives, veterans, and the military all get free healthcare paid for by the very people who can't afford insurance under the ACA or healthcare delivery.
Millennials are taking the penalty and I have resorted to using Seattle's health system.

Comment: I have been a high school English teacher for 15 years. I worked most of my life in Colorado. I now live and teach in Colombia. So, what I am proposing is that we start to teach bilingual classes for ALL students, starting in kindergarten. This way, our native English speakers can learn Spanish, and our native Spanish speakers can learn English.  This is what they are doing here, and my high school students are fluent in English by the time they are in high school. The efficacy of a bilingual education is proven!  It results in students who have better critical thinking skills as well as better cultural understanding. I am not worried about our current bilingual students, but I am worried that we need to raise our standards the country over to compete with European and South American schools that regularly graduate bilingual (trilingual, and more...) students every year. State schools need to realize the importance of creating more worldly students who can compete with everyone else!

Comment: I could support a one year wage freeze while we (they) figure out a workable revenue, budget, PFD system balance...    
Government wages in Alaska have always tended to follow Alaska private sector comparable wages, with a time lag for several good reasons (comp analyses, design of change packages, reviews & approvals by various administrative/legislative entities, review & passage by the Legislature) and they will again.... It happened when labor demand went up, and it will now as labor demand declines.
Private sector wages in Alaska have also followed Alaska isolation and competition factors more than national factors. Not too many places in Mississippi, Arizona or New York where a laborer or bed-maker can get room, board and $4,000/month or more.

Right now, in this session, they need to focus on MUCH LARGER revenue and spending fish that they need to fry - subsidies, taxes, PFD changes... This isn't "chump change" - but definitely second tier and ill-designed.

Comment: There are a lot of legitimate concerns in this article, but there are also reasons to think that they might be manageable by public policy, and in some cases by simple economics.

One thing that he doesn't mention, though, is that when autonomous vehicle usage is prevalent enough to justify having AV-only lanes, roads, or even highways, are transportation system will quickly become vastly more efficient. This mitigates several of the problems Mr Reguly is pointing out. When AVs don't have stretches where they don't have to contend with human-driven cars, they can go very very fast -- humans take about a second to react to a change in the traffic situation, whereas computers can assess, analyze, and act in a few milliseconds. Stop signs and traffic lights don't make sense at intersections where AV-only roads meet.

AVs can achieve the convenience of cars but much safer, cheaper, and more efficient. There is no reason that thoughtful policy can't mitigate the downsides.

Comment: A transgender person is one whose gender identity does not conform to expectations based on their assigned sex, and assigned sex is exactly that: how the delivering doctor described you based on inspection.  Some transgender persons do wish to undergo gender-affirmation surgery, some don't.  Gender identity is not a binary thing.  It's our culture that is set up that way, and conformance to gender stereotype is pretty much expected.  Also, gender-affirmation surgery is quite expensive, and until recently - and only if you have a job with great benefits - covered by insurance.  So the most that many transgender folks who want to transition can practically do is hormone treatments and of course social transition - presenting according to their gender identity. Hence the freakout.

So the issue here is really a very complicated one that requires a lot of discussion. And yes, greater use of gender-neutral or family restrooms with private stalls would. So too locker rooms...

Comment: I, too, am an adjunct; however at a community college.  We have the same situation, but our classes are outsourced to other adjuncts, but on-line.  The college has discovered it is cheaper to have one on-line class with 40 students, rather than 3 classes with 10-15 students.  Not only payroll, but also having 3 classrooms open.  Those that teach on-line classes not only have to be certified as an adjunct, but also pay for certification for teaching on-line.

While I do understand for English courses it seems fairly straight forward, but I teach remedial math classes.  Personally, I feel that people that have issues with math to begin with ought to be in a face-to-face class.

We'd be making it up as we go. And it would mean the court intervening in a governmental choice that was made for an extraordinary reason. I think the courts would be reluctant to go there, unless the government's choice was deeply and selectively damaging to people's Charter rights.

It's analogous to the situation where a government invokes a War Act. Certain rights may be suspended due to the extraordinary situation. Recognizing that the situation is both rare and existential, the courts typically do not challenge the government.

Comment: Claimed copies, the authenticity of which cannot be confirm, are not 'copies that exist' by any sane definition of that concept. They are not evidence by any scientific standard of the term 'evidence'.

None exist.

To say one existed, to claim evidence for it, you need either the original - or one that is verifiably an accurate copy from the original (or at the very least a verifiably accurate copy of a copy that was off the original and probably accurate).

Even if these copies were not in dispute as to their authenticity - we have absolutely no evidence that their content actually matches the originally. Hand-copying is notoriously unreliable and you frequently end up with important changes as the copying party alters things to suit his personal agenda.
It can even happen innocently. Monks who copied the bible for centuries often made notes in the margine. More than a few of those notes are now, likely, included in the main text because somebody later on didn't know they were notes

Comment: Frank, you are factually and theoretically incorrect about the population dynamics of feral cats. Comment: The chief reason why the TDSB wishes to quit using the word "chief" (derived from the French "chef", possibly the Latin "caput" and in everyday use since the 16th century) when referring to leadership positions is because in some contexts the word has a pejorative meaning. For example; "Too many chiefs and not enough Indians" or the names of various sports teams, etc. There are several words for leaders  in the various Indigenous languages like "sagamore" or "sachem", but even these have been somewhat Anglicize by translation. It would be a compliment to Indigenous people if Canadians called the Fire Chief the Fire Sachem, but that would be up to the people who used the term, not politicians.

Comment: Breathes there the man, with soul so dead,
Who never to himself hath said,
"This is my own, my native land!"
Whose heart hath ne'er within him burn'd,
As home his footsteps he hath turn'd,
From wandering on a foreign strand!
If such there breathe, go, mark him well;
For him no Minstrel raptures swell;
High though his titles, proud his name,
Boundless his wealth as wish can claim;
Despite those titles, power, and pelf,
The wretch, concentred all in self,
Living, shall forfeit fair renown,
And, doubly dying, shall go down
To the vile dust, from whence he sprung,
Unwept, unhonour'd, and unsung.

- Sir Walter Scott

Comment: That is a lot of cash. But why is it being grossly overpaid?

I'll play devil's advocate here (although I don't think of Frank Lawson as the devil). He is an MBA with direct responsibility for hundreds of employees and $1B in assets and >$100 million in revenue. 

In the private sector, companies with the same revenue have CEO compensation of $650,000. Companies with $10M or less (far less than EWEB) are paid $225,000 (in 2012). So Frank is underpaid, rightfully so, compared to private CEOs.

Non-profits with 10M+ in revenue have a mean executive compensation of $269,000. At $100-200M (EWEB range), the mean compensation is $460,000. 

So you'd really have to argue that everyone is overpaid (it's possible), or as O77 argues, that it would be possible to always attract talent capable of doing the job at a lower salary. Given the mixed competence at the current pay for different admins, I'm not sure that is true!

I will try. 

Home Bank and Home Trust are separate CDIC members (even though they are both part of the Home Capital group of companies) so deposits are insured separately. i.e. you can have $100K deposited in both and still be covered. 

Husband and wife each have $95K deposited in Home Bank. 

Husband and wife each have $5K deposited in Home Trust. 

They have a 'joint' deposit of $95K in Home Bank. 

They have a 'joint' deposit of $5K in Home Trust. 

So, no individual deposit in any one institution exceeds $100,000. 

'Joint' accounts are covered separately by CDIC. 

https://www.cdic.ca/en/about-di/how-it-works/Pages/more-than-one-name.aspx

As long as they withdraw the interest to ensure any one deposit does not exceed the $100K limit, they remain fully insured by CDIC.

Comment: Maybe it isn't harmful, but maybe it is. Maybe it can't be changed, but maybe it can. If it isn't harmful, and can't be changed, then us trying to do anything won't have any effect. If it is harmful, but can't be changed, we're all dead anyway, so trying to stop it won't have any effect. If it isn't harmful, but can be changed, then all we've done by trying to stop it is reset things to the way they were before.
