Coal, oil - these things are going to run out, and when they do, if we don't have alternatives in place, we are in deep trouble. Welcome to the dark ages.

Comment: Just taking up the question of those permit applicants who were also subject to TRO strictures, the problem in gathering useful statistics and using them in a meaningful way is that the act of a court imposing a TRO on someone does not always equate with that someone being a convicted felon or otherwise forbidden from owning a gun.  Of course the petitioner requesting a TRO needs to present a compelling case before a judge, but this does not by any means rise to the level of certainty of a criminal trial.  Regrettably, like someone who would accuse another person of rape or sexual assault, we would like to believe no TRO petitioner would dare to lie or make up stories, however, human beings are what they are.

I'm aware of individuals in this state who were not guilty of committing the acts that justified the imposition of a TRO.  Their names were eventually cleared and their 2nd Amendment rights finally restored, but I suspect sifting out these cases won't be as simple as it might be.

Comment: Look, this isn't rocket science. An okay decision about PERS years ago backfired largely because of stock market unpredictability: yeah, someone should have figured that out, but that's hardly out of line with the greatest financial wizards in the financial sector that brought us the Great Recession. So, face up to it: the state has some enormous debts to those who entered the system some time ago: for some time now, the situation has been different, severely limiting the liability.

But, back to now: no amount of chest-beating and whining will erase the debt. One can be childish and demand the state cut a budget that already has meant the collapse of one of the country's greatest school systems and many other important services. Or, responsible Oregonians can demand elected officials enact a tax increase and dedicate it specifically and irrevocably to the debt service: opposing it by saying government can't be trusted is so much Tea Party bull. Corporate tax or transportation?

Comment: I think everyone is feeling the challenges of an extraordinary snowy winter and is understanding that there may be disruptions in city services.  However, this situation is not new. The problem is no one at city hall ever learns their lesson and we see the same pattern of confusion by our city services and all they ever do is make the same excuse through the media.

Okay.  Mistakes happen and we all understand that but then the city is horribly slow to come up with a back up plans, and to communicate it publicly.    

The fact that City services is chaotic during a bad winter and shuts down should cause concern if Vancouver ever has a real catastrophe.

This in no way indicts the hard working city crews who are doing their best with limited resources.  The blame is on those at the city with the decision making power for budgets and resources.

Comment: Read up before you make a bigger fool of yourself.

" . . . . Aquinas distinguishes four kinds of law: (1) eternal law; (2) natural law; (3) human law; and (4) divine law.   Eternal law is comprised of those laws that govern the nature of an eternal universe; as Susan Dimock (1999, 22) puts it, one can "think of eternal law as comprising all those scientific (physical, chemical, biological, psychological, etc.) 'laws' by which the universe is ordered." Divine law is concerned with those standards that must be satisfied by a human being to achieve eternal salvation. One cannot discover divine law by natural reason alone; the precepts of divine law are disclosed only through divine revelation."

The natural law is comprised of those precepts of the eternal law that govern the behavior of beings possessing reason and free will. . . ."

Comment: "...you end up with nothing to show for it."

I disagree. Take an extreme case: I give you $1M and a choice of either 1) buying my house from me for $1M or 2) renting it from me for $100/month. Hopefully it's clear that even parking that $1M in a savings account at today's criminally low rates generates more than enough return to cover your annual shelter costs (including annual rent increases). Now imagine that you diversely invested that $1M instead - including in real estate holdings, if you were so-inclined. You would be debt free, portable, and have a growing net worth while also being able to take care of your shelter needs (heck, you could buy a parcel of land somewhere less expensive if you wanted a "roof over your head" back-up plan). 

The reality in places like the Lower Mainland isn't THAT extreme, but for many thinking people starting out today, the choice to rent over owning isn't about being poor; it's about sound financial analysis.

Comment: So, if all goes as planned, over 14,000 American troops in Afghanistan. 
Defence Secretary Jim Mattis says, “We’re not looking at a purely military strategy..."  

Okay, it's a familiar refrain (more in a moment), but I'm interested.  What else? "“All wars come to an end. Our job is to end it as quickly as possible without losing the very mission that we’ve recognized...”   Well, if that's not an end-it-quickly-as-possible military strategy, then WHAT IS IT?  No answer from the Secretary.  

A few answers--especially about strategies other than military--are found inside the best book I know about the Canadian Afghanistan experience, in which our troops made valiant efforts to change lives and livelihoods in that country. Social-building stuff. It's written by Canadian reporter Graeme Smith.  The very first line of the book--which I'll never forget:  "We lost the war in South Afghanistan and it broke my heart."
Read and find out why.

Comment: I’m almost beyond words. The world has lost a gem. Neil Davis, a high school dropout, was an incredible success story (and should be an inspiration to all). He went back to school, got his degrees, including a PhD. He contributed immensely to the scientific world: Poker Flats, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center and UAF’s Geophysical Institute. He contributed with books he authored on those and other subjects, including very entertaining fiction and non-fiction, ranging from politics to personal history. He was brilliant. He was delightfully entertaining. He worked hard. I am humbled and most grateful to have known and considered him among my closest friends/mentors. He will be missed. Condolences to his wonderful family.

Comment: In February, the Habs had almost no secondary scoring. Only 4 forwards scored in the entire month, and Pacioretty hauled nearly all the water himself. But in March, the opposite happened. The secondary scoring, if we can call it that, showed signs of life, and Pacioretty's line was fairly quiet. The Habs' record was better when the scoring was spread out a little more equitably and they scored more: 22 goals in 13 games in February, but 37 in 13 games in March. The fourth line, a combination of Mitchell, Flynn, Martinsen, Ott, McCarron, King, contributed 1 goal per month. That's not one goal each per month, that's one goal for the entire line per month. I believe the 4th line has already got their goal for April so for the 10 minutes a game they will play against the Rangers, expect tight checking nothingness. The offence plays a 50 minute game. 

So, while the Habs need Pacioretty to lead, if Byron,Gallagher, Lehkonen and Galchenyuk, lines 2 and 3, don't step up, could be a fast exit.

Comment: You make a few claims in your proposition that the market will a least limit health care costs. One is "My comments are based on basic economics." How are they based on basic economics? Does the desire to treat one's body or save one's life just another consumable like wanting a car or a TV? Who wants "budget" healthcare or life saving treatments? Would anyone ask, "is there a cheaper heart bypass that while not quite as good, still meets most people's needs?" If the rich can afford the greatest and most expensive care, does that not push prices up according to "basic economics"?
Another claim: "Cuba does not allow verification of their statistics; that means there is something to hide." Your logic to dismiss the Cuba stats is: not verifiable according to some criteria (what criteria?), if not verifiable, then something to hide, if hiding something, then not accurate stats. How do we know that? 
Using a different metric, maybe Cuba has more cost-effective healthcare?

Comment: nd crossing, you again use the north side crosswalk, and because of the advanced green for southbound mechanization turning east onto Gerrard, you can complete the crossing without being made to wait in many instances. As you cross the northbound lanes during the advanced green, you MUST however beware of drivers who want to turn north off gerrard, they have the right of way and you don't mess with that ever. But there's usually no one wanting to turn right, the flow is all turning southbound at that intersection (see note above). But, you also have to keep a weather eye out for drivers making a legal u-turn from the southbound University Avenue lanes right around to the northbound lanes, on the advanced green. They too have the right of way, and you just can't mess with that either. So, crossing eastbound the seam isn't nearly as safe as crossing westbound, but it still works most of the time.

Comment: Fred, I suggest you brush up on the, Canadian Human Rights Commission’s Policy on Alcohol and Drug Testing (2009) report.

If testing is part of a broader program of medical assessment, monitoring and support,
employers can test for alcohol in any of the following situations:
• on a random basis, for employees who hold safety-sensitive positions;
• for "reasonable cause," where an employee reports for work in an unfit state and
there is evidence of substance abuse;
• after a significant incident or accident has occurred and there is evidence that an
employee’s act or omission may have contributed to the incident or accident; or
• following treatment for alcohol abuse, or disclosure of a current alcohol
dependency or abuse.

Comment: Nice try and nice con. You sound like the person who produced the pro-Pebble ads.

Kennecott produced 260 pounds of copper for every ton of ore extracted, or a return rate of 13%. Pebble Mine is projected to yield a return of 0.34 of 1%  for a yield of 6.8 pounds per ton. That means that Pebble will have to extract roughly 16 trillion pounds of ore. The neutralizing carbonates used at Kennecott significantly mitigated the risk to the Copper River fish. The geology of the Pebble deposit does not contain significant volumes of neutralizing carbonates. Actually, it contains acidifying elements.

Comment: One problem is that the career paths set up at universities and corporations favours males. It is linear. If we shifted to a modular career path, something that zigged and zagged, women would find it more accommodating.

Also, a shorter work week would help. Men tend to identify themselves through work and that's why they prefer a 40 hour work week. However, life is not work alone. Certainly not if one has children or an elderly parent. (And as the Boomers age, the problem of eldercare will only increase.) Four six  hour days or three twelve hour days or whatever would go a long way to creating options for people who need to wear many hats.

Also, large companies and universities should have on-site day cares. There used to be an excellent one at the UofT. I'm not sure if it is still there as I recall the administration was eyeing the land for development when last I was there. It's very stressful for parents to have to do three-point commutes to drop off/pick up little ones.

Comment: Teaching self discipline is not achievable through any method so crude as punishment. There's a great deal to it, but at the very top of the list are two key principles:
1) Honesty. Nothing reduces a child's respect for authority faster than hypocrisy. Never make a rule for a child that you will not follow yourself. If you want your teens to be celibate, you better be celibate yourself, if you can't be  - then you'd best teach them about consent and safe sex instead. Don't lie about following the same rules either - they WILL find out. 
2)By example: if you want your children to respect  and obey your authority, set the example by respecting and obeying the authorities that exist over you. Never speed when driving. Never drink and drive. Obey even the laws you don't agree with. Even the ones you think are stupid. Pay your taxes, without complaint. Pay your TV license. As of that court decision: it means obeying the law against spanking them too.

Respect your kids and they'll respect u

Comment: If you use insurance of *any kind* you are being subsidized by other premium payers. 

People should especially remember that when their insurance covers accidents that require hundreds-of-thousands of dollars to save their lives, and if their lucky restore them to functioning health again. People should remember that when unhappily suffering a life-threatening disease that requires very expensive treatments to save them. When we create catastrophic medical bills that are largely covered by insurance, we have been subsidized by those who didn't suffer the same sort of disasters, *yet*. 

Everyone will suffer a catastrophic accident or illness eventually, and we all need to remember that sad fact. Except for the very wealthy, if we want to survive, or we want a loved one to survive, we will need to be subsidized or we will be denied.

Comment: "Court gives CNN win in labor dispute"?

Now that I've read the opinion that headline is seen to be even more in error. The court upheld that CNN was bound to negotiate as a "successor employer" and "the Board’s bottom-line conclusion that anti-union animus pervaded CNN’s hiring process", though it overturned some of the remediation. Further, the NLRB can reinstate its joint employer finding with a copy-and-paste of its explanation from an intervening opinion in  a case called  Browning-Ferris, assuming that the change in criteria declared in that case survives the concurrent appeal. The "win" declared here is almost entirely imaginary.

Comment: Annie, public relief offered by states to the "worthy poor" was very specific, and FAR less onerous than the outrageously massive welfare programs we fund today.  Welfare and entitlement programs account for nearly 60% of our national fiscal spending to the tune of 1.3 TRILLION dollars annually. Legality does not make anything morally right.  Theft is always wrong; even if it's legal.  Confiscating what someone earns by making such plunder legal is still theft. Raising taxes hurts the poor, because businesses will raise prices to pass the cost off to the consumer, including the poor.

Comment: I think this division of labor attitude is a hold over from the "good old days" when the men did all the physically demanding labor on farms, construction, factories ...
I am old enough to remember those times - a day during harvest and the men came home in the evening totally worn out and tired. The physical work required back then would destroy any of our modern snow flakes in a matter of hours. In the meantime the ladies kept house and made sure there was food on the table.

Today you sit in an air conditioned combine cab guided by GPS and listen to music - back then a crew of a dozen or so farmers, neighbours and farm hands, older children ... would be out with the sun rise and work till dark to bring in the grain harvest - or starve later. Different times.

Comment: G2,  I'll take a stab at this strictly from my point of view. First, what everyone is calling "clips" should really be called magazines. If a bad "person" was trying to to load his/her weapon via clip, it would really, really slow them down if it was a modern civilian semi-automatic weapon such as the AR family (M4/M16).  But for the purists out there, an M1 Garand (think WWII and Korea) a clip would be correct but it only holds 8 rounds. Spend some time on your search engine of choice and you'll see what I mean.
I own two AR type carbines and lots of thirty round magazines. Seldom do I ever fill them to max capacity but when I do, I do. The main reason is I don't want to bother with reloading so often. There are times when I just want to keep up a sustained rate of fire. Mostly this occurs when I am teaching somebody specific shooting techniques and/or circumstances.
If you haven't, take a trip over to the Bear's Den and shoot their Thompson sub-machine gun on semi and full automatic.

Comment: John, why stick to just oil? Why not focus on our fair share of our fisheries wealth? 

Do you find it fair that we only tax the value that commercial fish harvesters (primarily Alaskans with limited entry permits), and don't tax anything on the value exported commercial fish processors (primarily large multinational companies headquartered outside of Alaska)? That's how we currently do it - only tax the $2 billion in ex-vessel value and leave untouched the $4 billion that is exported from the state. 

A one-third "fair share" on the export value of seafood would generate $1.32 billion. Gee, if we had been properly taxing the commercial fishing industry since statehood, maybe we won't be in the dire financial straits that we find ourselves in today. 

But maybe you are right. Maybe we should just focus on the other elephant in the room.

Comment: The VA, DOD and all federal government employees all need to be on the same travel regulation.  Currently one pays x while the other pays y for the same z.  One wants this, while the other wants that, and another doesn't want anything at all.

The Va currently pays veterans 1/2 the amount a VA employee would receive for the same location.  I guess vets only need half as much to eat or half as much room to sleep? 

Government travel regulations for the US require a myriad of ways of documentation using multiple pay charts.  I'm not talking about different areas but the same location.

For example, mileage between Fairbanks and Anchorage is  paid $5 more for coming back than going down.  Either the VA is overpaying for coming back or they are underpaying for going down.  Which is it?

The VA pays 41.5 cents per mile.  Military retirees under 65 get .7 cents per mile and active duty gets 53.5 cents per mile.  Same road, different systems.

Uniformity would save time and money.

Comment: I don't think you realize anything. There is a procedure called batching. Separate products or mixes can be sent down the line in batches. Pipeline operators are regulated. Meaning watched. Meaning they have to meet regulations to keep their licences. It isn't 'tar' sands. Tar is a product produced from asphaltic crude oils (vs. paraffinic crudes). Bitumen contain asphaltenes meaning it is viscous (heavy) and difficult to transport at cooler temperatures (unless heated) or diluted to raise its specific gravity (API gravity). Dilbit can be cleaned up despite the horror stories being circulated. It is no less difficult than any other heavy oil.

Comment: The Slater/Roth argument re self-driving cars falls apart immediately when you consider where those marvelous autos would drive -- in the same congested streets and highways Oahu has now. Maybe it's time to reassess the proposal once made by E. Alvey Wright, Hawaii's Director of Transportation in the 1970s (you could look it up). He said there should be a limit on the number of vehicles each household can own.. Predictably, that was shot down immediately. But without a grade-separated commuting option, Honolulu remains with too many traffic-related problems and too few solutions   
What can be done right now to finish this project is to gather financial commitments from landowners and corporations that will benefit enormously from rail. It's almost a case of malfeasance for the City to not have factored In this funding source by now. Frank Fasi, for all his quirkiness, sought such public/private plans from the five companies that bid on his elevated rail project in the early 1990s.

Comment: I gather the commentators have never heard of ivf for humans. When you're dealing with endangered species there are world-wide data bases of DNA to ensure breeding is done to produce viable offspring that are not related and without passing on genetics known to produce deleterious effects. There is no "wild" any more; however there is good work being done to mitigate the damage to existing herds through anti-poaching and anti-trafficking efforts. The most successful programs work with locals and it becomes their interest to protect the animals. I'm certain you'd be surprised to know that zoo staff visit these places and assist on their time off, using their own resources.  The anti-captivity people need to visit modern zoos to learn what truly happens; start with the conservation pavilions.

Comment: Sorry, you need to sit down an rethink your comments.  Of course the complainant in a sexual assault complaint is questioned. Last, there is the issue of consent, because in many cases, the person who is the subject of the complaint will state it was consensual.

Comment: Every time there are testimonies, like this, I am so profoundly grateful. I used to work in mental health and addictions, & I saw the impact on the level of stigma associated with mental illness when Michael Wilson went public about having lost a family member to mental illness. It was profound. 

We desperately need someone--several someones--of Wilson's profile to "come out" about addiction. It's profoundly stigmatized--including by many members of the medical community who have had little to no education, training, or experience with people with substance use problems. 

No-one believes any more that mental illness is a moral failing, or a choice. But addiction? We're still in the dark ages in terms of our understandings--& are we ever judgemental. Comments on MSM articles often employ language that qualifies under the Criminal Code as hate language. 

So the more people who raise their hands and say "my family too--& it could have been different", the better we'll all be. Thank-you

Comment: The problem is that growth in the stock market and your Roth IRA does not equate to economic growth. That requires growth in consumer spending, hiring, jobs, and wages at a sustained higher rate than we have today. It is economic growth like that which is needed to generate increased tax revenues to pay off the deficit— and make up for the debt incurred to give out big tax cuts. A good example, is the record setting growth in the stock market with the recovery of the economy from 2010 through today together with the Bush and Obama tax cuts— the deficit grew enormously and economic growth was modest without sustained growth in consumer spending— the enormous engine that drives economic growth—spending lagged. Increasing value of the stock market has not driven investment to sustained job production— look at the cash held by corporations waiting for more spending and job growth that comes from the huge number of middle class consumers that drive consumer spending.

Comment: This is a great opportunity to take ownership in your community and develop a sense of efficacy in improving the world around you. Instead of asking, "What barriers are there to bike riding?" You can ask, "What can I do to make bike riding in my community safer and more enjoyable?" Can we get our youth involved in clean up efforts, both to develop a sense of citizenship and a heart for the homeless? Maybe a community bike coop can help these people get reliable transportation to get jobs and housing. Maybe your local representatives can pass budgets to improve bike infrastructure maintenance. Can bike advocacy be an instrument of change for homelessness and social justice?

Enjoy the eclipse, folks. And don't forget proper eye protection.

Comment: Having spent much of the last 37 years commercial fishing in and out of cold bay, false pass, and king cove, I have to wonder who in the world cares about whether or not there is a road from town to town out there - and who will actually spend the money to make it happen.  It makes very little sense to be against the road - just as it makes very little sense for the country to pay for a road from the Cove to Cold Bay.  
All the worry about a development precedent in a national refuge?? - trade for other land if that's the big issue. 
The money spent for the hovercraft  and the harbor and all the other projects in the Cove are enough. 
The big deal for the folks out west is really simple - why should a bunch of folks out of Seattle, Chicago, and Baltimore - be allowed to dictate to Alaskan indigenous people about the kind of roads allowed in their area.
We are flying to Mars these days - what's wrong with connecting two alaskan towns by a road?? Some cosmic gal losing sleep in seattle?

Comment: Dave, our climatologists are way short of definitive data as to the relative impact of modern global communities on climate change, versus the huge direct and indirect impacts of the forces of nature in this great universe in which our small sphere revolves.   Even the best of our global scientists, Nobel prizewinners or otherwise, are scratching the surface when it comes to understanding the universe and its climatological impacts. "General Work Visa

Comment: It takes the US Forest Service, discovering by accident, one of the many environmental toxic contaminant threats currently polluting this state of Oregon, solely because the state (and federal) public health and wildlife protection agencies cannot do their mandated responsibilities for detection, assessment, and public protection because legislatures are being irresponsible. The legislature sets the tone by funding, or withholding funding, of agency effort to effectively do their mandated work. For very many years, a culture has built up for the 'avoidance at any cost' of toxic contaminant monitoring unless some crisis in the media pushed a stop-gap blatant need. Agencies fear punitive legislative reductions of any agency that 'makes waves' by pointedly investigative work that could demonstrate ongoing toxic pollution for humans and wildlife. Legislatures erroneously see such investigatory monitoring as being inherently politically and fiscally subversive, but such work is essential.

Comment: Not a bad idea at all. There is a serious disconnect between actual value and assessed value, and I say that as an owner. Just make sure to phase it in and allocate the windfall to infrastructure spending, including transit as well as housing.
Trouble is, it's not politically expedient. As well, low-income people (especially the elderly) would need relief.

Comment: Moving the conversation off of the technical "can we shoot something down" debate, to what you said in your piece: "I think the first step has to be to stop thinking primarily of military solutions. None of those are pretty.", there is a point I feel needs to be made on this statement. 
First off, North Korea, China, the United Nations, the United States and South Korea have not signed off on any permanent peace agreement to end the Korean War. Until that becomes a reality, any re-thought of North Korea as anything but a military issue is foolhearty.
Second, the amount of side issues related to any peace agreement just between North and South Korea is quite long, and gets longer as the years go on and both sides develop separately from one another. As long as South Korea continues to adhere to a nuclear-free stance while North Korea does the opposite, a military solution is always going to be in play until the whole peninsula is nuclear free.
